references: M = 17 M 17 M=17 italic_M = 17  wafers processed on a single tool are considered for the dataset, where each datapoint is the etch rate measured on a single wafer at  N N N italic_N  different locations [ X , Y X Y X,Y italic_X , italic_Y ] on the surface, given by  W r , o superscript W r o W^{r,o} italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r , italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . A plot of the etch rates against radius for the  N N N italic_N  measurement points is depicted in  1  for a sample wafer. Three sensor parameters of interest are considered, with  ( m 1  , m 2  )  subscript m 1  subscript m 2 (\overset{\cdot}{m_{1}},\overset{\cdot}{m_{2}}) ( over start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , over start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG )  being the gas flow rate of the etching gas and the ashing gas into the chamber respectively and  P P P italic_P  being the power delivered by the electromagnetic field. The process recipes included in the training dataset are shown in table  I .

N ||x-x_{k}||\text{ }\forall\text{ }k\in 1\dots N | | italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | |  italic_k  1 ... italic_N , and  x x x italic_x  is the position vector of the interpolation point with respect to a global origin. The cartesian grid of points that form the interpolants have the extents  [  R , R ] R R [-R,R] [ - italic_R , italic_R ]  where R is the radius of the wafer in each dimension, with a spacing of  R / n R n R/n italic_R / italic_n . A heatmap of the scalar field is shown in Fig.  2 . The input scalar field is then scaled to have a value between  0 0  and  1 1 1 1  by dividing the etch rate field by a scalar value that is equal to the maximum measured etch rate in the dataset. The interpolated scalar field is then used to train the autoencoder, with the autoencoder generating a new scalar field  W g , u superscript W g u W^{g,u} italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g , italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
